content.title: Central Venous Stenosis
content.definition: Stenosis or occlusion of central veins (subclavian, brachiocephalic, or SVC) caused by prior central venous catheter placement, which compromises ipsilateral hemodialysis access function.

clinical_features.catheter: Prior or current central venous catheter (most common)
clinical_features.location: Subclavian vein most common, then brachiocephalic

concepts.definition: Signs and symptoms of central venous stenosis.

clinical_features.chest_wall_collaterals: Prominent chest wall and shoulder veins

clinical_features.fistulogram: Venogram with central runoff most useful
clinical_features.duplex: May show abnormal waveforms, cannot visualize central veins

clinical_features.angioplasty: First-line treatment, high recurrence (50-60% at 1 year)
clinical_features.stent: For elastic recoil or rapid recurrence
clinical_features.access_relocation: May need to relocate access to contralateral arm

clinical_features.prevention: Avoid subclavian catheters in ESRD patients
clinical_features.guideline: Internal jugular preferred for temporary dialysis access
